162  | /*++++
163  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
164  |  ** 									     **
165  |  **   Function:		store_hash_value				     **
166  |  ** 									     **
167  |  **   Description:	Keeps the old value of the variable around if it is  **
168  |  **			touched in the modulefile to enable undoing a	     **
169  |  **			modulefile by resetting the evironment to it started.**
170  |  ** 									     **
171  |  **			This is the same for unset_shell_variable()	     **
172  |  ** 									     **
173  |  **   First Edition:	1992/10/14					     **
174  |  ** 									     **
175  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_HashTable	*htable		Hash table to be used**
176  |  **			const char	*key		Attached key	     **
177  |  **			const char	*value		Alias value	     **
178  |  ** 									     **
179  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful completion	     **
180  |  ** 									     **
181  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
182  |  ** 									     **
183  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
184  |  ++++*/
185  | 
186  | int store_hash_value(	Tcl_HashTable* htable,
187  |         		const char*    key,
188  |         		const char*    value)
189  | {
190  |     int   		 new;		/** Return from Tcl_CreateHashEntry  **/
191  | 					/** which indicates creation or ref- **/
192  | 					/** ference to an existing entry     **/
193  |     char		*tmp;		/** Temp pointer used for disalloc.  **/
194  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hentry;	/** Hash entry reference	     **/
195  | 
196  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
197  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_store_hash_value, NULL);
198  | #endif
199  | 
200  |     /**
201  |      **  Create a hash entry for the key to be stored. If there exists one
202  |      **  so far, its value has to be unlinked.
203  |      **  All values in this hash are pointers to allocated memory areas.
204  |      **/
205  | 
206  |     hentry = Tcl_CreateHashEntry( htable, (char*) key, &new);
207  |     if( !new) {
208  | 	tmp = (char *) Tcl_GetHashValue( hentry);
209  |     	if( tmp)
210  | 	    null_free((void *) &tmp);
211  |     }
212  | 
213  |     /**
214  |      **  Set up the new value. stringer allocates!
215  |      **/
216  | 
217  |     if( value)
218  |         Tcl_SetHashValue( hentry, (char*) stringer(NULL,0, value,NULL));
219  |     else
220  |         Tcl_SetHashValue( hentry, (char*) NULL);
221  |     
222  |     return( TCL_OK);
223  | 
224  | } /** End of 'store_hash_value' **/
225  | 
226  | /*++++
227  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
228  |  ** 									     **
229  |  **   Function:		clear_hash_value				     **
230  |  ** 									     **
231  |  **   Description:	Remove the specified shell variable from the passed  **
232  |  **			hash table					     **
233  |  ** 									     **
234  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
235  |  ** 									     **
236  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_HashTable	*htable		Hash table to be used**
237  |  **			const char	*key		Attached key	     **
238  |  ** 									     **
239  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful completion	     **
240  |  ** 									     **
241  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
242  |  ** 									     **
243  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
244  |  ++++*/
245  | 
246  | int clear_hash_value(	Tcl_HashTable	*htable,
247  |                        	const char	*key)
248  | {
249  |     char		*tmp;		/** Temp pointer used for dealloc.   **/
250  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hentry;	/** Hash entry reference	     **/
251  | 
252  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
253  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_clear_hash_value, NULL);
254  | #endif
255  | 
256  |     /**
257  |      **  If I haven't already created an entry for keeping this environment
258  |      **  variable's value, then just leave.
259  |      **  Otherwise, remove this entry from the hash table.
260  |      **/
261  | 
262  |     if( (hentry = Tcl_FindHashEntry( htable, (char*) key)) ) {
263  | 
264  |         tmp = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( hentry);
265  |         if( tmp)
266  | 	    null_free((void *) &tmp);
267  | 
268  |         Tcl_DeleteHashEntry( hentry);
269  |     }
270  |     
271  |     return( TCL_OK);
272  | 
273  | } /** End of 'clear_hash_value' **/
274  | 
275  | /*++++
276  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
277  |  ** 									     **
278  |  **   Function:		Clear_Global_Hash_Tables			     **
279  |  ** 									     **
280  |  **   Description: 	Deletes and reinitializes our env. hash tables.	     **
281  |  ** 									     **
282  |  **   First Edition:	1992/10/14					     **
283  |  ** 									     **
284  |  **   Parameters:	-						     **
285  |  **   Result:		-						     **
286  |  ** 									     **
287  |  **   Attached Globals:	setenvHashTable,				     **
288  |  **			unsetenvHashTable,				     **
289  |  **			aliasSetHashTable,				     **
290  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable				     **
291  |  ** 									     **
292  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
293  |  ++++*/
294  | 
295  | static	void	Clear_Global_Hash_Tables( void)
296  | {
297  |     Tcl_HashSearch	 searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
298  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hashEntry;	/** Result from Tcl hash search      **/
299  |     char		*val = NULL;	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
300  | 
301  |     /**
302  |      **  The following hash tables are to be initialized
303  |      **/
304  | 
305  |     Tcl_HashTable	*table[5],
306  | 			**table_ptr = table;
307  | 
308  |     table[0] = setenvHashTable;
309  |     table[1] = unsetenvHashTable;
310  |     table[2] = aliasSetHashTable;
311  |     table[3] = aliasUnsetHashTable;
312  |     table[4] = NULL;
313  | 
314  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
315  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Clear_Global_Hash_Tables, NULL);
316  | #endif
317  | 
318  |     /**
319  |      **  Loop for all the hash tables named above. If there's no value stored
320  |      **  in a hash table, skip to the next one. 
321  |      **/
322  | 
323  |     for( ; *table_ptr; table_ptr++) {
324  | 
325  | 	if( ( hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( *table_ptr, &searchPtr)) == NULL) 
326  | 	    continue;
327  | 	
328  | 	/**
329  | 	 **  Otherwise remove all values stored in the table
330  | 	 **/
331  | 
332  | 	do {
333  | 	    val = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( hashEntry);
334  | 	    if( val)
335  | 		null_free((void *) &val);
336  | 	} while( (hashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
337  | 
338  | 	/**
339  | 	 **  Reinitialize the hash table by unlocking it from memory and 
340  | 	 **  thereafter initializing it again.
341  | 	 **/
342  | 
343  | 	Tcl_DeleteHashTable( *table_ptr);
344  | 	Tcl_InitHashTable( *table_ptr, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
345  | 
346  |     } /** for **/
347  | 
348  | } /** End of 'Clear_Global_Hash_Tables' **/
349  | 
350  | /*++++
351  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
352  |  ** 									     **
353  |  **   Function:		Delete_Global_Hash_Tables			     **
354  |  **			Delete_Hash_Tables				     **
355  |  ** 									     **
356  |  **   Description: 	Deletes our environment hash tables.		     **
357  |  ** 									     **
358  |  **   First Edition:	1992/10/14					     **
359  |  ** 									     **
360  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_HashTable	**table_ptr	NULL-Terminated list **
361  |  **							of hash tables to be **
362  |  **							deleted		     **
363  |  **   Result:		-						     **
364  |  ** 									     **
365  |  **   Attached Globals:	setenvHashTable,				     **
366  |  **			unsetenvHashTable,				     **
367  |  **			aliasSetHashTable,				     **
368  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable				     **
369  |  ** 									     **
370  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
371  |  ++++*/
372  | 
373  | void Delete_Global_Hash_Tables( void) {
374  | 
375  |     /**
376  |      **  The following hash tables are to be initialized
377  |      **/
378  | 
379  |     Tcl_HashTable	*table[5];
380  | 
381  |     table[0] = setenvHashTable;
382  |     table[1] = unsetenvHashTable;
383  |     table[2] = aliasSetHashTable;
384  |     table[3] = aliasUnsetHashTable;
385  |     table[4] = NULL;
386  | 
387  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
388  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Delete_Global_Hash_Tables, NULL);
389  | #endif
390  | 
391  |     Delete_Hash_Tables( table);
392  | 
393  | } /** End of 'Delete_Global_Hash_Tables' **/
394  | 
395  | void Delete_Hash_Tables( Tcl_HashTable	**table_ptr)
396  | {
397  | 
398  |     Tcl_HashSearch	 searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
399  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hashEntry;	/** Result from Tcl hash search      **/
400  |     char		*val = NULL;	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
401  | 
402  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
403  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Delete_Hash_Tables, NULL);
404  | #endif
405  | 
406  |     /**
407  |      **  Loop for all the hash tables named above. Remove all values stored in
408  |      **  the table and then free up the whole table
409  |      **/
410  |     for( ; *table_ptr; table_ptr++) {
411  | 
412  |         if( ( hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( *table_ptr, &searchPtr))) {
413  | 
414  | 	    /**
415  | 	     **  Remove all values stored in the table
416  | 	     **/
417  | 	    do {
418  | 		val = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( hashEntry);
419  | 		if( val)
420  | 		    null_free((void *) &val);
421  | 	    } while( (hashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
422  | 
423  | 	    /**
424  | 	     **  Remove internal hash control structures
425  | 	     **/
426  | 	    Tcl_DeleteHashTable( *table_ptr);
427  | 	}
428  | 
429  | 	null_free((void *) table_ptr);
430  | 
431  |     } /** for **/
432  | 
433  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
434  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_Delete_Hash_Tables, NULL);
435  | #endif
436  | 
437  | } /** End of 'Delete_Hash_Tables' **/
438  | 
439  | /*++++
440  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
441  |  ** 									     **
442  |  **   Function:		Copy_Hash_Tables				     **
443  |  ** 									     **
444  |  **   Description:	Allocate new hash tables for the global environment, **
445  |  **			initialize them and copy the contents of the current **
446  |  **			tables into them.				     **
447  |  ** 									     **
448  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
449  |  ** 									     **
450  |  **   Parameters:	-						     **
451  |  **   Result:		Tcl_HashTable**		Pointer to the new list of   **
452  |  **						hash tables		     **
453  |  **   Attached Globals:	setenvHashTable,				     **
454  |  **			unsetenvHashTable,				     **
455  |  **			aliasSetHashTable,				     **
456  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable				     **
457  |  ** 									     **
458  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
459  |  ++++*/
460  | 
461  | Tcl_HashTable	**Copy_Hash_Tables( void)
462  | {
463  |     Tcl_HashSearch	  searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
464  |     Tcl_HashEntry	 *oldHashEntry,	/** Hash entries to be copied	     **/
465  | 			 *newHashEntry;
466  |     char		 *val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
467  |     			 *key = NULL;	/** Hash key			     **/
468  |     int			  new;		/** Tcl inidicator, if the new hash  **/
469  | 					/** entry has been created or ref.   **/
470  | 
471  |     Tcl_HashTable	 *oldTable[5],
472  | 			**o_ptr, **n_ptr,
473  | 			**newTable;	/** Destination hash table	     **/
474  | 
475  |     oldTable[0] = setenvHashTable;
476  |     oldTable[1] = unsetenvHashTable;
477  |     oldTable[2] = aliasSetHashTable;
478  |     oldTable[3] = aliasUnsetHashTable;
479  |     oldTable[4] = NULL;
480  | 
481  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
482  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Copy_Hash_Tables, NULL);
483  | #endif
484  | 
485  |     /**
486  |      **  Allocate storage for the new list of hash tables
487  |      **/
488  |     if( !(newTable = (Tcl_HashTable**) module_malloc( sizeof( oldTable))))
489  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
490  | 	    goto unwind0;
491  | 
492  |     /**
493  |      **  Now copy each hashtable out of the list
494  |      **/
495  |     for( o_ptr = oldTable, n_ptr = newTable; *o_ptr; o_ptr++, n_ptr++) {
496  | 
497  | 	/**
498  | 	 **  Allocate memory for a single hash table
499  | 	 **/
500  | 	if( !(*n_ptr = (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof( Tcl_HashTable))))
501  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
502  | 		goto unwind1;
503  | 
504  | 	/**
505  | 	 **  Initialize that guy and copy it from the old table
506  | 	 **/
507  | 	Tcl_InitHashTable( *n_ptr, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
508  |         if( (oldHashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( *o_ptr, &searchPtr)) ) {
509  | 
510  | 	    /**
511  | 	     **  Copy all entries if there are any
512  | 	     **/
513  | 	    do {
514  | 
515  | 		key = (char*) Tcl_GetHashKey( *o_ptr, oldHashEntry);
516  | 		val = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( oldHashEntry);
517  | 
518  | 		newHashEntry = Tcl_CreateHashEntry( *n_ptr, key, &new);
519  | 
520  | 		if(val)
521  |         	    Tcl_SetHashValue(newHashEntry, stringer(NULL,0, val, NULL));
522  | 		else
523  | 		    Tcl_SetHashValue(newHashEntry, (char *) NULL);
524  | 
525  | 	    } while( (oldHashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
526  | 
527  | 	} /** if **/
528  |     } /** for **/
529  | 
530  |     /**
531  |      **  Put a terminator at the end of the new table
532  |      **/
533  |     *n_ptr = NULL;
534  | 
535  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
536  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_Copy_Hash_Tables, NULL);
537  | #endif
538  | 
539  |     return( newTable);
540  | 
541  | unwind1:
542  |     null_free((void *) &newTable);
543  | unwind0:
544  |     return( NULL);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
545  | } /** End of 'Copy_Hash_Tables' **/
546  | 
547  | /*++++
548  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
549  |  ** 									     **
550  |  **   Function:								     **
551  |  ** 									     **
552  |  **   Description:	Once a the loading or unloading of a modulefile	     **
553  |  **			fails, any changes it has made to the environment    **
554  |  **			must be undone and reset to its previous state. This **
555  |  **			function is responsible for unwinding any changes a  **
556  |  **			modulefile has made.				     **
557  |  ** 									     **
558  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
559  |  ** 									     **
560  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	 *interp	According TCL interp.**
561  |  **			Tcl_HashTable	**oldTables	Hash tables storing  **
562  |  **							the former environm. **
563  |  **   Result:								     **
564  |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
565  |  ** 									     **
566  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
567  |  ++++*/
568  | 
569  | int Unwind_Modulefile_Changes(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp, 
570  | 				Tcl_HashTable	**oldTables )
571  | {
572  |     Tcl_HashSearch	 searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
573  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hashEntry;	/** Result from Tcl hash search      **/
574  |     char		*val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
575  | 			*key;		/** Tcl hash key		     **/
576  |     int			 i;		/** Loop counter		     **/
577  | 
578  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
579  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Unwind_Modulefile_Changes, NULL);
580  | #endif
581  | 
582  |     if( oldTables) {
583  | 
584  | 	/**
585  | 	 **  Use only entries 0 and 1 which do contain all changes to the 
586  | 	 **  shell varibles (setenv and unsetenv)
587  | 	 **/
588  | 
589  | 	/** ??? What about the aliases (table 2 and 3) ??? **/
590  | 
591  | 	for( i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
592  | 	    if( (hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( oldTables[i], &searchPtr)) ) {
593  | 
594  | 		do {
595  | 		    key = (char*) Tcl_GetHashKey( oldTables[i], hashEntry);
596  | 
597  | 		    /**
598  | 		     **  The hashEntry will contain the appropriate value for the
599  | 		     **  specified 'key' because it will have been aquired depending
600  | 		     **  upon whether the unset or set table was used.
601  | 		     **/
602  | 
603  | 		    val = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( hashEntry);
604  | 		    if( val)
605  | 			Tcl_SetVar2( interp, "env", key, val, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
606  | 
607  | 		} while( (hashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
608  | 
609  | 	    } /** if **/
610  | 	} /** for **/
611  | 
612  | 	/**
613  | 	 **  Delete and reset the hash tables now that the current contents have been
614  | 	 **  flushed.
615  | 	 **/
616  | 
617  | 	Delete_Global_Hash_Tables();
618  | 
619  | 	setenvHashTable     = oldTables[0];
620  | 	unsetenvHashTable   = oldTables[1];
621  | 	aliasSetHashTable   = oldTables[2];
622  | 	aliasUnsetHashTable = oldTables[3];
623  | 
624  |     } else {
625  | 
626  | 	Clear_Global_Hash_Tables();
627  | 
628  |     }
629  | 
630  |     return( TCL_OK);
631  | 
632  | } /** End of 'Unwind_Modulefile_Changes' **/
633  | 
634  | static int keycmp(const void *a, const void *b) {
635  | 	return strcmp(*(const char **) a, *(const char **) b);
636  | }
637  |                                                                                 
638  | /*++++
639  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
640  |  ** 									     **
641  |  **   Function:		Output_Modulefile_Changes			     **
642  |  ** 									     **
643  |  **   Description:	Is used to flush out the changes of the current	     **
644  |  **			modulefile in a manner depending upon whether the    **
645  |  **			modulefile was successful or unsuccessful.	     **
646  |  ** 									     **
647  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
648  |  ** 									     **
649  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp		The attached Tcl in- **
650  |  **							terpreter	     **
651  |  ** 									     **
652  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
653  |  ** 									     **
654  |  **   Attached Globals:	setenvHashTable,				     **
655  |  **			unsetenvHashTable,				     **
656  |  **			aliasSetHashTable,	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
657  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
658  |  **			change_dir		for the chdir command	     **
659  |  ** 									     **
660  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
661  |  ++++*/
662  | 
663  | int Output_Modulefile_Changes(	Tcl_Interp	*interp)
664  | {
665  |     Tcl_HashSearch	  searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
666  |     Tcl_HashEntry	 *hashEntry;	/** Result from Tcl hash search      **/
667  |     char		 *val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
668  | 			 *key,		/** Tcl hash key		     **/
669  | 			**list;		/** list of keys		     **/
670  |     int			  i,k;		/** Loop counter		     **/
671  |     size_t		  hcnt;		/** count of hash entries	     **/
672  | 
673  |     /**
674  |      **  The following hash tables do contain all changes to be made on
675  |      **  shell variables
676  |      **/
677  | 
678  |     Tcl_HashTable	*table[2];
679  | 
680  |     table[0] = setenvHashTable;
681  |     table[1] = unsetenvHashTable;
682  |   
683  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
684  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Output_Modulefile_Changes, NULL);
685  | #endif
686  | 
687  |     aliasfile = stdout;
688  | 
689  |     /**
690  |      **  Scan both tables that are of interest for shell variables
691  |      **/
692  | 
693  |     for(i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
694  | 	/* count hash */
695  | 	hcnt = countTclHash(table[i]);
696  | 
697  | 	/* allocate array for keys */
698  | 	if( !(list = (char **) module_malloc(hcnt * sizeof(char *)))) {
699  | 		if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
700  | 	    		return(TCL_ERROR);/** ------- EXIT (FAILURE) ------> **/
701  | 	}
702  | 
703  | 	/* collect keys */
704  | 	k = 0;
705  | 	if( (hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( table[i], &searchPtr)) )
706  | 		do {
707  | 			key = (char*) Tcl_GetHashKey( table[i], hashEntry);
708  | 			list[k++] = stringer(NULL,0, key, NULL);
709  | 		} while( (hashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
710  | 	/* sort hash */
711  | 	if (hcnt > 1)
712  | 		qsort((void *) list, hcnt, sizeof(char *), keycmp);
713  | 
714  | 	/* output key/values */
715  | 	for (k = 0; k < hcnt; ++k) {
716  | 		key = list[k];
717  |     		hashEntry = Tcl_FindHashEntry( table[i], key);
718  | 		/**
719  | 		 **  The table list indicator is used in order to differ
720  | 		 **  between the setenv and unsetenv operation
721  | 		 **/
722  | 		if( i == 1) {
723  | 			output_unset_variable( (char*) key);
724  | 		} else {
725  | 			if( (val=(char *) Tcl_GetVar2(interp,"env",
726  | 			    key,TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY)) )
727  | 				output_set_variable(interp, (char*) key, val);
728  | 		}
729  | 	} /** for **/
730  | 	/* delloc list */
731  | 	for (k = 0; k < hcnt; ++k)
732  | 		free(list[k]);
733  | 	free(list);
734  |     } /** for **/
735  | 
736  |     if( EOF == fflush( stdout))
737  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_FLUSH, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
738  | 	    return( TCL_ERROR);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
739  | 
740  |     Output_Modulefile_Aliases( interp);
741  |     Output_Directory_Change( interp);
742  | 
743  |     /**
744  |      **  Delete and reset the hash tables since the current contents have been
745  |      **  flushed.
746  |      **/
747  | 
748  |     Clear_Global_Hash_Tables();
749  |     return( TCL_OK);
750  | 
751  | } /* End of 'Output_Modulefile_Changes' */ 
752  | 
753  | /*++++
754  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
755  |  ** 									     **
756  |  **   Function:		Open_Aliasfile					     **
757  |  ** 									     **
758  |  **   Description:	Creates/opens or closes temporary file for sourcing  **
759  |  **			or aliases.					     **
760  |  **			Passes back the filehandle and filename in global    **
761  |  ** 			variables.					     **
762  |  ** 									     **
763  |  **   First Edition:	2005/09/26	R.K.Owen <rk@owen.sj.ca.us>	     **
764  |  ** 									     **
765  |  **   Parameters:	int	action		if != 0 to open else close   **
766  |  ** 									     **
767  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
768  |  ** 									     **
769  |  **   Attached Globals: aliasfile					     **
770  |  **			aliasfilename					     **
771  |  ** 									     **
772  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
773  |  ++++*/
774  | 
775  | static	int Open_Aliasfile(int action)
776  | {
777  |     if (action) {
778  | 	/**
779  | 	 **  Open the file ...
780  | 	 **/
781  | 	if( tmpfile_mod(&aliasfilename,&aliasfile))
782  | 	    if(OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_OPEN, LOC, aliasfilename,
783  | 		_(em_appending), NULL))
784  | 		return( TCL_ERROR);	/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
785  |     } else {
786  | 	if( EOF == fclose( aliasfile))
787  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, aliasfilename, NULL))
788  | 		return( TCL_ERROR);	/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
789  |     }
790  | 
791  |     return( TCL_OK);
792  | 
793  | } /** End of 'Open_Aliasfile' **/
794  | /*++++
795  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
796  |  ** 									     **
797  |  **   Function:		Output_Modulefile_Aliases			     **
798  |  ** 									     **
799  |  **   Description:	Is used to flush out the changes to the aliases of   **
800  |  **			the current modulefile. But, some shells don't work  **
801  |  **			well with having their alias information set via the **
802  |  **			'eval' command.  So, what we'll do now is output the **
803  |  **			aliases into a /tmp dotfile, have the shell source   **
804  |  **			the /tmp dotfile and then have the shell remove the  **
805  |  **			/tmp dotfile.					     **
806  |  ** 									     **
807  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
808  |  ** 									     **
809  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp		The attached Tcl in- **
810  |  **							terpreter	     **
811  |  ** 									     **
812  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
813  |  ** 									     **
814  |  **   Attached Globals: aliasSetHashTable,	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
815  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
816  |  ** 									     **
817  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
818  |  ++++*/
819  | 
820  | static	int Output_Modulefile_Aliases( Tcl_Interp *interp)
821  | {
822  |     Tcl_HashSearch	 searchPtr;	/** Tcl hash search handle	     **/
823  |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hashEntry;	/** Result from Tcl hash search      **/
824  |     char		*val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
825  | 			*key;		/** Tcl hash key		     **/
826  |     int			 i,		/** Loop counter		     **/
827  | 			 openfile = 0;	/** whether using a file or not	     **/
828  |     char		*sourceCommand; /** Command used to source the alias **/
829  | 
830  |     /**
831  |      **  The following hash tables do contain all changes to be made on
832  |      **  shell aliases
833  |      **/
834  |     Tcl_HashTable	*table[2];
835  | 
836  |     table[0] = aliasSetHashTable;
837  |     table[1] = aliasUnsetHashTable;
838  | 
839  |     /**
840  |      **  If configured so, all changes to aliases are written into a temporary
841  |      **  file which is sourced by the invoking shell ...
842  |      **  In this case a temporary filename has to be assigned for the alias
843  |      **  source file. The file has to be opened as 'aliasfile'.
844  |      **  The default for aliasfile, if no shell sourcing is used, is stdout.
845  |      **/
846  | 
847  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
848  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Output_Modulefile_Aliases, NULL);
849  | #endif
850  | 
851  |     /**
852  |      **  We only need to output stuff into a temporary file if we're setting
853  |      **  stuff.  We can unset variables and aliases by just using eval.
854  |      **/
855  |     if( (hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( aliasSetHashTable, &searchPtr)) ) {
856  | 
857  | 	/**
858  | 	 **  We must use an aliasfile if EVAL_ALIAS is not defined
859  | 	 **  or the sh shell does not do aliases (HAS_BOURNE_ALIAS)
860  | 	 **  and that the sh shell does do functions (HAS_BOURNE_FUNCS)
861  | 	 **/
862  | 	if (!eval_alias
863  | 	|| (!strcmp(shell_name,"sh") && !bourne_alias && bourne_funcs)) {
864  | 	    if (OK != Open_Aliasfile(1))
865  | 		if(OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_OPEN,LOC,aliasfilename,
866  | 		    _(em_appending),NULL))
867  | 		    return( TCL_ERROR);	/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
868  | 	    openfile = 1;
869  | 	}
870  | 	/**
871  | 	 **  We only support sh and csh variants for aliases.  If not either
872  | 	 **  sh or csh print warning message and return
873  | 	 **/
874  | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
875  | 	if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "csh")) {
876  | 	    sourceCommand = "source %s%s";
877  | 	} else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "sh")) {
878  | 	    sourceCommand = ". %s%s";
879  | 	} else {
880  | 	    return( TCL_ERROR);	/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
881  | 	}
882  | 
883  | 	if (openfile) {
884  | 	    /**
885  | 	     **  Only the source command has to be flushed to stdout. After
886  | 	     **  sourcing the alias definition (temporary) file, the source
887  | 	     **  file is to be removed.
888  | 	     **/
889  | 	    alias_separator = '\n';
890  | 
891  | 	    fprintf( stdout, sourceCommand, aliasfilename, shell_cmd_separator);
892  | 	    fprintf( stdout, "/bin/rm -f %s%s",
893  | 		aliasfilename, shell_cmd_separator);
894  | 	} /** openfile **/
895  |     } /** if( alias to set) **/
896  | 
897  |     /**
898  |      **  Scan the hash tables involved in changing aliases
899  |      **/
900  | 
901  |     for( i=0; i<2; i++) {
902  |     
903  | 	if( (hashEntry = Tcl_FirstHashEntry( table[i], &searchPtr)) ) {
904  | 
905  | 	    do {
906  | 		key = (char*) Tcl_GetHashKey( table[i], hashEntry);
907  | 		val = (char*) Tcl_GetHashValue( hashEntry);
908  | 
909  | 		/**
910  | 		 **  The hashtable list index is used to differ between aliases
911  | 		 **  to be set and aliases to be reset
912  | 		 **/
913  | 		if(i == 1) {
914  | 		    output_unset_alias( key, val);
915  | 		} else {
916  | 		    output_set_alias( key, val);
917  | 		}
918  | 
919  | 	    } while( (hashEntry = Tcl_NextHashEntry( &searchPtr)) );
920  | 
921  | 	} /** if **/
922  |     } /** for **/
923  | 
924  | 
925  |     if(openfile) {
926  | 	if( OK != Open_Aliasfile(0))
927  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, aliasfilename, NULL))
928  | 		return( TCL_ERROR);	/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
929  | 
930  | 	null_free((void *) &aliasfilename);
931  |     }
932  | 
933  |     return( TCL_OK);
934  | 
935  | } /** End of 'Output_Modulefile_Aliases' **/
936  | 
937  | /*++++
938  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
939  |  **									     **
940  |  **   Function:		Output_Directory_Change				     **
941  |  **									     **
942  |  **   Description:	Changes the current working directory.               **
943  |  **									     **
944  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp *interp	The attached Tcl interpreter **
945  |  **									     **
946  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
947  |  **				TCL_ERROR	When not applicable	     **
948  |  **									     **
949  |  **   Attached Global:  change_dir					     **
950  |  **									     **
951  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
952  |  ++++*/
953  | static	int Output_Directory_Change(Tcl_Interp *interp)
954  | {
955  | 	int rc = TCL_OK;
956  | 
957  | 	if (change_dir == NULL)
958  | 		return rc;
959  | 
960  | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
961  | 	if(!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh") || !strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
962  | 		fprintf(stdout, "cd '%s'%s", change_dir, shell_cmd_separator);
963  | 	} else if(!strcmp( shell_derelict, "perl")) {
964  | 		fprintf(stdout, "chdir '%s'%s", change_dir, shell_cmd_separator);
965  | 	} else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "python")) {
966  | 		fprintf(stdout, "os.chdir('%s')\n", change_dir);
967  | 	} else {
968  | 		rc = TCL_ERROR;
969  | 	}
970  | 
971  | 	free(change_dir);
972  | 	change_dir = NULL;
973  | 
974  | 	return rc;
975  | }
976  | 
977  | 
978  | /*++++
979  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
980  |  ** 									     **
981  |  **   Function:		output_set_variable				     **
982  |  ** 									     **
983  |  **   Description:	Outputs the command required to set a shell variable **
984  |  **			according to the current shell			     **
985  |  ** 									     **
986  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
987  |  ** 									     **
988  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp	The attached Tcl interpreter **
989  |  **   			const char	*var	Name of the variable to be   **
990  |  **						set			     **
991  |  **			const char	*val	Value to be assigned	     **
992  |  **									     **
993  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Finished successful	     **
994  |  **				TCL_ERROR	Unknown shell type	     **
995  |  **									     **
996  |  **   Attached Globals:	shell_derelict					     **
997  |  ** 									     **
998  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
999  |  ++++*/
1000 | 
1001 | static	int	output_set_variable(	Tcl_Interp	*interp,
1002 | 					const char	*var,
1003 |           	          		const char	*val)
1004 | {
1005 | 
1006 |     /**
1007 |      **  Differ between the different kinds od shells at first
1008 |      **
1009 |      **  CSH
1010 |      **/
1011 |     chop( val);
1012 |     chop( var);
1013 | 
1014 |     assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1015 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1016 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_output_set_variable, " var='", var,
1017 | 	"' val= '", val, "'", NULL);
1018 | #endif
1019 | 
1020 |     if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1021 | 
1022 | #ifdef LMSPLIT_SIZE
1023 | 
1024 | 	/**
1025 | 	 **  Many C Shells (specifically the Sun one) has a hard limit on
1026 | 	 **  the size of the environment variables around 1k.  The
1027 | 	 **  _LMFILES_ variable can grow beyond 1000 characters.  So, I'm
1028 | 	 **  going to break it up here since I can put it back together
1029 | 	 **  again when I use it.
1030 | 	 **
1031 | 	 **  You can set the split size using --with-split-size=<number>
1032 | 	 **  it should probably be <1000.  I don't count the size of
1033 | 	 **  "setenv _LMFILES_xxx" so subtract this from your limit.
1034 | 	 **/
1035 | 	if( !strcmp( var, "_LMFILES_")) {
1036 | 	    char formatted[ MOD_BUFSIZE];
1037 | 	    char *cptr;
1038 | 	    int	lmfiles_len;
1039 | 	    int	count = 0;
1040 | 	    char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1041 | 	    EscapeCshString(val,escaped);
1042 | 
1043 | 	    if(( lmfiles_len = strlen(escaped)) > LMSPLIT_SIZE) {
1044 | 
1045 | 	    char buffer[ LMSPLIT_SIZE + 1];
1046 | 
1047 | 	    /**
1048 | 	     **  Break up the _LMFILES_ variable...
1049 | 	     **/
1050 | 	    while( lmfiles_len > LMSPLIT_SIZE) {
1051 | 
1052 | 		    strncpy( buffer, ( escaped + count*LMSPLIT_SIZE ),
1053 | 			     LMSPLIT_SIZE);
1054 | 		buffer[ LMSPLIT_SIZE] = '\0';
1055 | 
1056 | 		fprintf( stdout, "setenv %s%03d %s%s", var, count, buffer,
1057 | 		    shell_cmd_separator);
1058 | 
1059 | 		lmfiles_len -= LMSPLIT_SIZE;
1060 | 		count++;
1061 | 	    }
1062 | 
1063 | 		if( lmfiles_len) {
1064 | 		fprintf( stdout, "setenv %s%03d %s%s", var, count,
1065 | 		    (escaped + count*LMSPLIT_SIZE), shell_cmd_separator);
1066 | 		    count++;
1067 | 		}
1068 | 
1069 | 	    /**
1070 | 		 ** Unset _LMFILES_ as indicator to use the multi-variable
1071 | 		 ** _LMFILES_
1072 | 	     **/
1073 | 	    fprintf(stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1074 | 
1075 | 	    } else {	/** if ( lmfiles_len = strlen(val)) > LMSPLIT_SIZE) **/
1076 | 
1077 | 		fprintf(stdout, "setenv %s %s%s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator);
1078 | 	    }
1079 | 
1080 | 	    /**
1081 | 	     ** Unset the extra _LMFILES_%03d variables that may be set
1082 | 	     **/
1083 | 	    do {
1084 | 		sprintf( formatted, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1085 | 		cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env", formatted, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1086 | 		if( cptr) {
1087 | 		    fprintf(stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", formatted, shell_cmd_separator);
1088 | 		}
1089 | 	    } while( cptr);
1090 | 	
1091 | 	  null_free((void *) &escaped);
1092 | 
1093 | 	} else {	/** if( var == "_LMFILES_") **/
1094 | 
1095 | #endif /* not LMSPLIT_SIZE */
1096 | 	  
1097 | 		char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1098 | 		EscapeCshString(val,escaped);
1099 | 		fprintf(stdout, "setenv %s %s %s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator);
1100 | 		null_free((void *) &escaped);
1101 | #ifdef LMSPLIT_SIZE
1102 | 	}
1103 | #endif /* not LMSPLIT_SIZE */
1104 | 
1105 |     /**
1106 |      **  SH
1107 |      **/
1108 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1109 | 
1110 |       char* escaped = (char*)module_malloc(strlen(val)*2+1);
1111 |       EscapeShString(val,escaped);
1112 | 
1113 |       fprintf( stdout, "%s=%s %sexport %s%s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator,
1114 | 	       var, shell_cmd_separator);
1115 |       free(escaped);
1116 |       
1117 |     /**
1118 |      **  EMACS
1119 |      **/
1120 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "emacs")) {
1121 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(setenv \"%s\" \'%s\')\n", var, val);
1122 | 
1123 |     /**
1124 |      **  PERL
1125 |      **/
1126 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "perl")) {
1127 | 		char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1128 | 		EscapePerlString(val,escaped);
1129 | 		fprintf(stdout, "$ENV{'%s'} = '%s'%s", var, escaped,
1130 | 			shell_cmd_separator);  
1131 | 		null_free((void *) &escaped);
1132 | 
1133 |     /**
1134 |      **  PYTHON
1135 |      **/
1136 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "python")) {
1137 | 	fprintf( stdout, "os.environ['%s'] = '%s'\n", var, val);
1138 | 
1139 |     /**
1140 |      ** SCM
1141 |      **/
1142 |     } else if ( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "scm")) {
1143 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(putenv \"%s=%s\")\n", var, val);
1144 | 
1145 |     /**
1146 |      ** MEL (Maya Extension Language)
1147 |      **/
1148 |     } else if ( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "mel")) {
1149 |         fprintf( stdout, "putenv \"%s\" \"%s\";", var, val);
1150 | 
1151 |     /**
1152 |      **  Unknown shell type - print an error message and 
1153 |      **  return on error
1154 |      **/
1155 |     } else {
1156 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DERELICT, LOC, shell_derelict, NULL))
1157 | 	    return( TCL_ERROR);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1158 |     }
1159 | 
1160 |     /**
1161 |      **  Return and acknowldge success
1162 |      **/
1163 |     g_output = 1;
1164 |     return( TCL_OK);
1165 | 
1166 | } /** End of 'output_set_variable' **/
1167 | 
1168 | /*++++
1169 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1170 |  ** 									     **
1171 |  **   Function:		output_unset_variable				     **
1172 |  ** 									     **
1173 |  **   Description:	Outputs the command required to unset a shell        **
1174 |  **			variable according to the current shell		     **
1175 |  ** 									     **
1176 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1177 |  ** 									     **
1178 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*var	Name of the variable to be   **
1179 |  **						unset			     **
1180 |  **									     **
1181 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Finished successful	     **
1182 |  **				TCL_ERROR	Unknown shell type	     **
1183 |  **									     **
1184 |  **   Attached Globals:	shell_derelict					     **
1185 |  ** 									     **
1186 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1187 |  ++++*/
1188 | 
1189 | static	int	output_unset_variable( const char* var)
1190 | {
1191 |     chop( var);
1192 | 
1193 |     assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1194 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1195 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_output_unset_variable, NULL);
1196 | #endif
1197 | 
1198 |     /**
1199 |      **  Display the 'unsetenv' command according to the current invoking shell.
1200 |      **/
1201 |     if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1202 | 	fprintf( stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1203 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1204 | 	fprintf( stdout, "unset %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1205 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "emacs")) {
1206 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(setenv \"%s\" nil)\n", var);
1207 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "perl")) {
1208 | 	fprintf( stdout, "delete $ENV{'%s'}%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);  
1209 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "python")) {
1210 |       fprintf( stdout, "os.environ['%s'] = ''\ndel os.environ['%s']\n",var,var);
1211 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "scm")) {
1212 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(putenv \"%s\")\n", var);
1213 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "mel")) {
1214 | 	fprintf( stdout, "putenv \"%s\" \"\";", var);
1215 |     } else {
1216 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DERELICT, LOC, shell_derelict, NULL))
1217 | 	    return( TCL_ERROR);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1218 |     }
1219 | 
1220 |     /**
1221 |      **  Return and acknowldge success
1222 |      **/
1223 |     g_output = 1;
1224 |     return( TCL_OK);
1225 | 
1226 | } /** End of 'output_unset_variable' **/
1227 | 
1228 | /*++++
1229 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1230 |  ** 									     **
1231 |  **   Function:		output_function					     **
1232 |  ** 									     **
1233 |  **   Description:	Actually turns the Modules set-alias information     **
1234 |  **			into a string that a shell can source.  Previously,  **
1235 |  **			this routine just output the alias information to be **
1236 |  **			eval'd by the shell.				     **
1237 |  ** 									     **
1238 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1239 |  ** 									     **
1240 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*var	Name of the alias to be set  **
1241 |  **			const char	*val	Value to be assigned	     **
1242 |  ** 									     **
1243 |  **   Result:		-						     **
1244 |  ** 									     **
1245 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile,	The output file for alias commands.  **
1246 |  **					see 'Output_Modulefile_Aliases'      **
1247 |  **			alias_separator					     **
1248 |  ** 									     **
1249 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1250 |  ++++*/
1251 | 
1252 | static	void	output_function(	const char	*var,
1253 | 					const char	*val)
1254 | {
1255 |     const char *cptr = val;
1256 |     int nobackslash = 1;
1257 | 
1258 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1259 |     ErrorLogger(NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_output_function, NULL);
1260 | #endif
1261 | 
1262 |     /**
1263 |      **  This opens a function ...
1264 |      **/
1265 |     fprintf(aliasfile, "%s() { ", var);
1266 | 
1267 |     /**
1268 |      **  ... now print the value. Print it as a single line and remove any
1269 |      **  backslashes, and substitute a safe $*
1270 |      **/
1271 |     while (*cptr) {
1272 | 
1273 | 	if (*cptr == '\\') {
1274 | 	    if (!nobackslash)
1275 | 		putc(*cptr, aliasfile);
1276 | 	    else
1277 | 		nobackslash = 0;
1278 | 	    cptr++;
1279 | 	    continue;
1280 | 	} else if (*cptr == '$' && (cptr + 1) && (*(cptr + 1) == '*')) {
1281 | 	    /* found $* */
1282 | 	    fputs("${1+\"$@\"}", aliasfile);
1283 | 	    cptr++;
1284 | 	    cptr++;
1285 | 	    continue;
1286 | 	} else
1287 | 	    nobackslash = 1;
1288 | 
1289 | 	putc(*cptr++, aliasfile);
1290 | 
1291 |     } /** while **/
1292 | 
1293 |     /**
1294 |      **  Finally close the function
1295 |      **/
1296 |     fprintf(aliasfile, "%c}%c", alias_separator, alias_separator);
1297 | 
1298 | } /** End of 'output_function' **/
1299 | 
1300 | /*++++
1301 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1302 |  ** 									     **
1303 |  **   Function:		output_set_alias				     **
1304 |  ** 									     **
1305 |  **   Description:	Flush the commands required to set shell aliases de- **
1306 |  **			pending on the current invoking shell		     **
1307 |  ** 									     **
1308 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1309 |  ** 									     **
1310 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*alias		Name of the alias    **
1311 |  **			const char	*val		Value to be assigned **
1312 |  ** 									     **
1313 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Operation successful	     **
1314 |  ** 									     **
1315 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile, 	The alias command is written out to  **
1316 |  **			alias_separator Defined the command separator	     **
1317 |  **			shell_derelict	to determine the shell family	     **
1318 |  **			shell_name	to determine the real shell type     **
1319 |  ** 									     **
1320 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1321 |  ++++*/
1322 | 
1323 | static	int	output_set_alias(	const char	*alias,
1324 |                			  	const char	*val)
1325 | {
1326 |     int nobackslash = 1;		/** Controls whether backslashes are **/
1327 | 					/** to be print			     **/
1328 |     const char *cptr = val;		/** Scan the value char by char	     **/
1329 | 
1330 |     assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1331 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1332 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_output_set_alias, NULL);
1333 | #endif
1334 | 
1335 |     /**
1336 |      **  Check for the shell family
1337 |      **  CSHs need to switch $* to \!* and $n to \!\!:n unless the $ has a
1338 |      **  backslash before it
1339 |      **/
1340 |     if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1341 | 
1342 | 	/**
1343 | 	 **  On CSHs the command is 'alias <name> <value>'. Print the beginning
1344 | 	 **  of the command and then print the value char by char.
1345 | 	 **/
1346 |         fprintf( aliasfile, "alias %s '", alias);
1347 | 
1348 |         while( *cptr) {
1349 | 
1350 | 	    /**
1351 | 	     **  Convert $n to \!\!:n
1352 | 	     **/
1353 |             if( *cptr == '$' && nobackslash) {
1354 |                 cptr++;
1355 |                 if( *cptr == '*')
1356 |                     fprintf( aliasfile, "\\!");
1357 |                 else
1358 |                     fprintf( aliasfile, "\\!\\!:");
1359 |             }
1360 | 
1361 | 	    /**
1362 | 	     **  Recognize backslashes
1363 | 	     **/
1364 |             if( *cptr == '\\') {
1365 |                 if( !nobackslash)
1366 | 		    putc( *cptr, aliasfile);
1367 |                 else
1368 | 		    nobackslash = 0;
1369 |                 cptr++;
1370 |                 continue;
1371 |             } else
1372 |                 nobackslash = 1;
1373 | 
1374 | 	    /**
1375 | 	     **  print the read character
1376 | 	     **/
1377 |             putc( *cptr++, aliasfile);
1378 | 
1379 |         } /** while **/
1380 |  
1381 | 	/**
1382 | 	 **  Now close up the command using the alias command terminator as
1383 | 	 **  defined in the global variable
1384 | 	 **/
1385 |         fprintf( aliasfile, "'%c", alias_separator);
1386 | 
1387 |     /**
1388 |      **  Bourne shell family: The alias has to be  translated into a
1389 |      **  function using the function call 'output_function'
1390 |      **/
1391 |     } else if( !strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1392 | 	/**
1393 | 	 **  Shells supporting extended bourne shell syntax ....
1394 | 	 **/
1395 | 	if( (!strcmp( shell_name, "sh") && bourne_alias)
1396 | 		||  !strcmp( shell_name, "bash")
1397 |                 ||  !strcmp( shell_name, "zsh" )
1398 |                 ||  !strcmp( shell_name, "ksh")) {
1399 | 	    /**
1400 | 	     **  in this case we only have to write a function if the alias
1401 | 	     **  takes arguments. This is the case if the value has '$'
1402 | 	     **  somewhere in it without a '\' in front.
1403 | 	     **/
1404 | 	    while( *cptr) {
1405 | 		if( *cptr == '\\') {
1406 | 		    if( nobackslash) {
1407 | 			nobackslash = 0;
1408 | 		    }
1409 | 		} else {
1410 | 	    	   if( *cptr == '$') {
1411 | 			if( nobackslash) {
1412 | 				output_function( alias, val);
1413 | 				return TCL_OK;
1414 | 			}
1415 | 		    }
1416 | 		    nobackslash = 1;
1417 | 		}
1418 | 		cptr++;
1419 | 	    }
1420 | 
1421 |             /**
1422 |              **  So, we can just output an alias with '\$' translated to '$'...
1423 |              **/
1424 | 	    fprintf( aliasfile, "alias %s='", alias);
1425 | 
1426 | 	    nobackslash = 1;
1427 | 	    cptr = val;
1428 | 
1429 | 	    while( *cptr) {
1430 | 		if( *cptr == '\\') {
1431 | 		    if( nobackslash) {
1432 | 			nobackslash = 0;
1433 | 			cptr++;
1434 | 			continue;
1435 | 		    }
1436 | 		}
1437 | 		nobackslash = 1;
1438 | 
1439 | 		putc(*cptr++, aliasfile);
1440 | 
1441 | 	    } /** while **/
1442 | 
1443 | 	    fprintf( aliasfile, "'%c", alias_separator);
1444 | 
1445 |         } else if( !strcmp( shell_name, "sh")
1446 | 		&&   bourne_funcs) {
1447 | 	/**
1448 | 	 **  The bourne shell itself
1449 |          **  need to write a function unless this sh doesn't support
1450 | 	 **  functions (then just punt)
1451 | 	 **/
1452 |             output_function(alias, val);
1453 |         }
1454 | 	/** ??? Unknown derelict ??? **/
1455 | 
1456 |     } /** if( sh ) **/
1457 | 
1458 |     return( TCL_OK);
1459 | 
1460 | } /** End of 'output_set_alias' **/
1461 | 
1462 | /*++++
1463 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1464 |  ** 									     **
1465 |  **   Function:		output_unset_alias				     **
1466 |  ** 									     **
1467 |  **   Description:	Flush the commands required to reset shell aliases   **
1468 |  **			depending on the current invoking shell		     **
1469 |  ** 									     **
1470 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1471 |  ** 									     **
1472 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*alias		Name of the alias    **
1473 |  **			const char	*val		Value which has been **
1474 |  **							assigned	     **
1475 |  ** 									     **
1476 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Operation successful	     **
1477 |  ** 									     **
1478 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile, 	The alias command is writte out to   **
1479 |  **			alias_separator Defined the command separator	     **
1480 |  **			shell_derelict	to determine the shell family	     **
1481 |  **			shell_name	to determine the real shell type     **
1482 |  ** 									     **
1483 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1484 |  ++++*/
1485 | 
1486 | static	int	output_unset_alias(	const char	*alias,
1487 | 					const char	*val)
1488 | {
1489 |     int nobackslash = 1;		/** Controls wether backslashes are  **/
1490 | 					/** to be print			     **/
1491 |     const char *cptr = val;	/** Need to read the value char by char      **/
1492 | 
1493 |     assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1494 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1495 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_output_unset_alias, NULL);
1496 | #endif
1497 | 
1498 |     /**
1499 |      **  Check for the shell family at first
1500 |      **  Ahh! CSHs ... ;-)
1501 |      **/
1502 |     if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1503 |         fprintf( aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1504 | 
1505 |     /**
1506 |      **  Hmmm ... bourne shell types ;-(
1507 |      **  Need to unset a function in case of sh or if the alias took parameters
1508 |      **/
1509 |     } else if( !strcmp( shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1510 | 
1511 |         if( !strcmp( shell_name, "sh")) {
1512 | 	    if (bourne_alias) {
1513 | 		fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1514 | 	    } else if (bourne_funcs) {
1515 |         	fprintf(aliasfile,"unset -f %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1516 | 	    } /* else do nothing */
1517 | 	/**
1518 | 	 **  BASH
1519 | 	 **/
1520 |         } else if( !strcmp( shell_name, "bash")) {
1521 | 
1522 |             /**
1523 |              **  If we have what the old value should have been, then look to
1524 |              **  see if it was a function or an alias because bash spits out an
1525 |              **  error if you try to unalias a non-existent alias.
1526 |              **/
1527 |             if(val) {
1528 | 
1529 |                 /**
1530 |                  **  Was it a function?
1531 |                  **  Yes, if it has arguments...
1532 |                  **/
1533 | 		while( *cptr) {
1534 | 		    if( *cptr == '\\') {
1535 | 			if( nobackslash) {
1536 | 			    nobackslash = 0;
1537 | 			}
1538 | 		    } else {
1539 | 		if(*cptr == '$') {
1540 | 			    if( nobackslash) {
1541 | 				fprintf(aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias,
1542 | 				        alias_separator);
1543 | 		    return TCL_OK;
1544 | 			    }
1545 | 			}
1546 | 			nobackslash = 1;
1547 | 		    }
1548 | 		    cptr++;
1549 | 		}
1550 | 
1551 |                 /**
1552 |                  **  Well, it wasn't a function, so we'll put out an unalias...
1553 |                  **/
1554 | 		    fprintf( aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1555 | 
1556 |             } else {	/** No value known (any more?) **/
1557 | 
1558 |                 /**
1559 |                  **  We'll assume it was a function because the unalias command
1560 |                  **  in bash produces an error.  It's possible that the alias
1561 |                  **  will not be cleared properly here because it was an
1562 |                  **  unset-alias command.
1563 |                  **/
1564 |                 fprintf( aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1565 |             }
1566 | 
1567 | 	/**
1568 | 	 **  ZSH or KSH
1569 | 	 **  Put out both because we it could be either a function or an
1570 | 	 **  alias.  This will catch both.
1571 | 	 **/
1572 | 
1573 |         } else if( !strcmp( shell_name, "zsh")){
1574 | 
1575 |             fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1576 | 
1577 |         } else if( !strcmp( shell_name, "ksh")) {
1578 | 
1579 |             fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1580 |             fprintf(aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1581 | 
1582 |         } /** if( bash, zsh, ksh) **/
1583 | 
1584 | 	/** ??? Unknown derelict ??? **/
1585 | 
1586 |     } /** if( sh-family) **/
1587 |     
1588 |     return( TCL_OK);
1589 | 
1590 | } /** End of 'output_unset_alias' **/
1591 | 
1592 | /*++++
1593 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1594 |  ** 									     **
1595 |  **   Function:		getLMFILES					     **
1596 |  ** 									     **
1597 |  **   Description:	Read in the _LMFILES_ environment variable. This one **
1598 |  **			may be split into several variables cause by limited **
1599 |  **			variable space of some shells (esp. the SUN csh)     **
1600 |  ** 									     **
1601 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1602 |  ** 									     **
1603 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp    *interp	Attached Tcl interpreter     **
1604 |  ** 									     **
1605 |  **   Result:		char*	Value of the environment varibale _LMFILES_  **
1606 |  ** 									     **
1607 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
1608 |  ** 									     **
1609 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1610 |  ++++*/
1611 | 
1612 | char	*getLMFILES( Tcl_Interp	*interp)
1613 | {
1614 |     static char	*lmfiles = NULL;	/** Buffer pointer for the value     **/
1615 | 
1616 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1617 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getLMFILES, NULL);
1618 | #endif
1619 | 
1620 |     /**
1621 |      **  Try to read the variable _LMFILES_. If the according buffer pointer
1622 |      **  contains a value, disallocate it before.
1623 |      **/
1624 |     if( lmfiles)
1625 |         null_free((void *) &lmfiles);
1626 | 
1627 |     lmfiles = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env","_LMFILES_",TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1628 | 
1629 |     /**
1630 |      **  Now the pointer is NULL in case of the variable has not been defined.
1631 |      **  In this case try to read in the splitted variable from _LMFILES_xxx
1632 |      **/
1633 |     if( !lmfiles) {
1634 | 
1635 |         char	buffer[ MOD_BUFSIZE];	/** Used to set up the split variab- **/
1636 | 					/** les name			     **/
1637 |         int	count = 0;		/** Split part count		     **/
1638 |         int	lmsize = 0;		/** Total size of _LMFILES_ content  **/
1639 |         int	old_lmsize;		/** Size save buffer		     **/
1640 |         int	cptr_len;		/** Size of the current split part   **/
1641 |         char	*cptr;			/** Split part read pointer	     **/
1642 | 
1643 | 	/**
1644 | 	 **  Set up the split part environment variable name and try to read it
1645 | 	 **  in
1646 | 	 **/
1647 |         sprintf( buffer, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1648 |         cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env", buffer, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1649 | 
1650 |         while( cptr) {			/** Something available		     **/
1651 | 
1652 | 	    /**
1653 | 	     **  Count up the variables length
1654 | 	     **/
1655 |             cptr_len = strlen( cptr);	
1656 |             old_lmsize = lmsize;
1657 |             lmsize += cptr_len;
1658 |  
1659 | 	    /**
1660 | 	     **  Reallocate the value's buffer and copy the current split
1661 | 	     **  part at its end
1662 | 	     **/
1663 |             if((char *) NULL == (lmfiles =
1664 | 		(char*) realloc( lmfiles, lmsize * sizeof(char) + 1))) {
1665 | 		    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
1666 | 			return( NULL);		/** ---- EXIT (FAILURE) ---> **/
1667 | 	    }
1668 |             
1669 |             strncpy( lmfiles + old_lmsize, cptr, cptr_len);
1670 |             *(lmfiles + old_lmsize + cptr_len) = '\0';
1671 |  
1672 | 	    /**
1673 | 	     **  Read the next split part variable
1674 | 	     **/
1675 |             sprintf( buffer, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1676 |             cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp,"env",buffer, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1677 |         }
1678 | 
1679 |     } else {  /** if( lmfiles) **/
1680 | 
1681 | 	/**
1682 | 	 **  If the environvariable _LMFILES_ has been set, copy the contents
1683 | 	 **  of the returned buffer into a free allocated one in order to
1684 | 	 **  avoid side effects.
1685 | 	 **/
1686 | 	char	*tmp = stringer(NULL,0, lmfiles, NULL);
1687 | 
1688 | 	if( !tmp)
1689 | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
1690 | 		return( NULL);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1691 | 
1692 | 	/** 
1693 | 	 **  Set up lmfiles pointing to the new buffer in order to be able to
1694 | 	 **  disallocate when invoked next time.
1695 | 	 **/
1696 |         lmfiles = tmp;
1697 | 
1698 |     } /** if( lmfiles) **/
1699 | 
1700 |     /**
1701 |      **  Return the received value to the caller
1702 |      **/
1703 |     return( lmfiles);
1704 | 
1705 | } /** end of 'getLMFILES' **/
1706 | 
1707 | /*++++
1708 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1709 |  ** 									     **
1710 |  **   Function:		IsLoaded					     **
1711 |  ** 									     **
1712 |  **   Description:	Check wether the passed modulefile is currently      **
1713 |  **			loaded						     **
1714 |  ** 									     **
1715 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1716 |  ** 									     **
1717 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp       *interp	According Tcl interp.**
1718 |  **			char             *modulename	Name of the module to**
1719 |  **							be searched for	     **
1720 |  **			char            **realname	Buffer for the name  **
1721 |  **							and version of the   **
1722 |  **							module that has mat- **
1723 |  **							ched the query	     **
1724 |  **			char             *filename	Buffer to store the  **
1725 |  **							whole filename of a  **
1726 |  **							found loaded module  **
1727 |  **									     **
1728 |  **   Result:		int	0	Requested module not loaded	     **
1729 |  **				1	module is loaded		     **
1730 |  **									     **
1731 |  **			realname	points to the name of the module that**
1732 |  **					has matched the query. If this poin- **
1733 |  **					differs form 'modulename' after this **
1734 |  **					function has finished, the buffer for**
1735 |  **					to store the module name in has been **
1736 |  **					allocated here.			     **
1737 |  **					if (char **) NULL is passed, no buf- **
1738 |  **					fer will be allocated		     **
1739 |  **				??? Is this freed correctly by the caller ???**
1740 |  **									     **
1741 |  **			filename	will be filled with the full module  **
1742 |  **					file path of the module that has     **
1743 |  **					matched the query		     **
1744 |  **									     **
1745 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
1746 |  ** 									     **
1747 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1748 |  ++++*/
1749 | 
1750 | /**
1751 |  **  Check all possibilities of module-versions
1752 |  **/
1753 | 
1754 | int IsLoaded(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1755 | 		char		 *modulename,
1756 | 		char		**realname,
1757 | 		char		 *filename )
1758 | {
1759 |     return( __IsLoaded( interp, modulename, realname, filename, 0));
1760 | }
1761 | 
1762 | /**
1763 |  **  Check only an exact match of the passed module and version
1764 |  **/
1765 | int IsLoaded_ExactMatch(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1766 | 				char		 *modulename,
1767 | 				char		**realname,
1768 | 				char		 *filename )
1769 | {
1770 |     return( __IsLoaded( interp, modulename, realname, filename, 1));
1771 | }
1772 | 
1773 | /**
1774 |  **  The subroutine __IsLoaded finally checks for the requested module being
1775 |  **  loaded or not.
1776 |  **/
1777 | static int __IsLoaded(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1778 | 			char		 *modulename,
1779 | 			char		**realname,
1780 | 			char		 *filename,
1781 | 			int		  exact)
1782 | {
1783 |     char *l_modules = NULL;		/** Internal module list buffer	     **/
1784 |     char *l_modulefiles = NULL;		/** Internal module file list buffer **/
1785 |     char *loaded = NULL;		/** Buffer for the module            **/
1786 |     char *basename = NULL;		/** Pointer to module basename       **/
1787 |     char *loadedmodule_path = NULL;	/** Pointer to one loaded module out **/
1788 | 					/** of the loaded modules list	     **/
1789 |     int   count = 0;
1790 | 
1791 |     /**
1792 |      **  Get a list of loaded modules (environment variable 'LOADEDMODULES')
1793 |      **  and the list of loaded module-files (env. var. __LMFILES__)
1794 |      **/
1795 |     char	*loaded_modules = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env",
1796 | 			"LOADEDMODULES", TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1797 |     char	*loaded_modulefiles = getLMFILES( interp);
1798 |     
1799 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
1800 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc___IsLoaded, NULL);
1801 | #endif
1802 | 
1803 |     /**
1804 |      **  If no module is currently loaded ... the requested module is surely
1805 |      **  not loaded, too ;-)
1806 |      **/
1807 |     if( !loaded_modules) 
1808 | 	goto unwind0;
1809 |     
1810 |     /**
1811 |      **  Copy the list of currently loaded modules into a new allocated array
1812 |      **  for further handling. If this fails it will be assumed, that the 
1813 |      **  module is *NOT* loaded.
1814 |      **/
1815 |     if((char *) NULL == (l_modules = stringer(NULL,0,loaded_modules,NULL)))
1816 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1817 | 	    goto unwind0;
1818 | 
1819 |     /**
1820 |      **  Copy the list of currently loaded modulefiles into a new allocated
1821 |      **  array for further handling. If this failes it will be assumed, that
1822 |      **  the module is *NOT* loaded.
1823 |      **/
1824 |     if(loaded_modulefiles)
1825 | 	if((char *) NULL == (l_modulefiles = stringer(NULL,0,
1826 | 		loaded_modulefiles,NULL)))
1827 | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1828 | 		goto unwind1;
1829 | 
1830 |     /**
1831 |      **  Assume the modulename given was an exact match so there is no
1832 |      **  difference to return -- this will change in the case it wasn't an
1833 |      **  exact match below
1834 |      **/
1835 |     if( realname)
1836 |         *realname = modulename;
1837 | 
1838 |     if( *l_modules) {
1839 | 
1840 | 	/**
1841 | 	 **  Get each single module which is loaded by splitting up at colons
1842 | 	 **  The variable LOADEDMODULES contains a list of modulefile like the
1843 | 	 **  following:
1844 | 	 **                gnu/2.0:openwin/3.0
1845 | 	 **/
1846 | 	loadedmodule_path = xstrtok( l_modules, ":");
1847 | 	while( loadedmodule_path) {
1848 | 
1849 | 	    if((char *) NULL == (loaded = stringer(NULL,0,
1850 | 		    loadedmodule_path,NULL)))
1851 | 		if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1852 | 		    goto unwind2;
1853 | 
1854 | 	    /**
1855 | 	     **  Get a modulefile without a version and check if this is the
1856 | 	     **  requested one.
1857 | 	     **/
1858 | 	    if( !strcmp( loaded, modulename)) {	/** FOUND    **/
1859 | 
1860 | 		null_free ((void *) &loaded);
1861 | 		break;			/** leave the while loop	     **/
1862 | 
1863 | 	    } else if( !exact) {		/** NOT FOUND	     **/
1864 | 
1865 | 		/**
1866 | 		 **  Try to more and more simplify the modulename by removing
1867 | 		 **  all detail (version) information
1868 | 		 **/
1869 | 		basename = get_module_basename( loaded);
1870 | 		while( basename && strcmp( basename, modulename)) {
1871 | 		    basename = get_module_basename( basename);
1872 |                 }
1873 | 
1874 | 		/**
1875 | 		 **  Something left after splitting again? If yes the requested
1876 | 		 **  module is found!
1877 |                  **  Since the name given was a basename, return the fully
1878 | 		 **  loaded path
1879 | 		 **/
1880 |                 if( basename) {
1881 | 		    null_free ((void *) &loaded);
1882 |                     if( realname)
1883 | 			if((char *) NULL == (*realname = stringer(NULL,0,
1884 | 				loadedmodule_path,NULL)))
1885 | 			    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1886 | 				goto unwind2;
1887 | 
1888 | 		    break;		/** leave the while loop	     **/
1889 | 
1890 | 		} /** if( basename) **/
1891 | 	    } /** if not found with single basename **/
1892 | 
1893 | 	    /**
1894 | 	     **  Get the next entry from the loaded modules list
1895 | 	     **/
1896 | 	    loadedmodule_path = xstrtok( NULL, ":");
1897 |             count++;
1898 | 
1899 | 	    null_free ((void *) &loaded); /** Free what has been alloc. **/
1900 | 
1901 | 	} /** while **/
1902 |     } /** if( *l_modules) **/
1903 | 
1904 |     /**
1905 |      **  If we found something locate it's associated modulefile
1906 |      **/
1907 |     if( loadedmodule_path) {
1908 |         if( filename && l_modulefiles && *l_modulefiles) {
1909 | 
1910 | 	    /**
1911 | 	     **  The position of the loaded module within the list of loaded
1912 | 	     **  modules has been counted in 'count'. The position of the 
1913 | 	     **  associated modulefile should be the same. So tokenize the
1914 | 	     **  list of modulefiles by the colon until the wanted position
1915 | 	     **  is reached.
1916 | 	     **/
1917 |             char* modulefile_path = xstrtok(l_modulefiles, ":");
1918 | 	
1919 |             while( count) {
1920 |                 if( !( modulefile_path = xstrtok( NULL, ":"))) {
1921 | 
1922 | 		    /**
1923 | 		     **  Oops! Fewer entries in the list of loaded modulefiles
1924 | 		     **  than in the list of loaded modules. This will
1925 | 		     **  generally suggest that _LMFILES_ has become corrupted,
1926 | 		     **  but it may just mean we're working intermittantly with
1927 | 		     **  an old version.  So, I'll just not touch filename which
1928 | 		     **  means the search will continue using the old method of
1929 | 		     **  looking through MODULEPATH.  
1930 |                      */
1931 | 		    goto success0;
1932 |                 }
1933 |                 count--;
1934 | 
1935 |             } /** while **/
1936 | 
1937 | 	    /**
1938 | 	     **  Copy the result into the buffer passed from the caller
1939 | 	     **/
1940 |             strcpy( filename, modulefile_path);
1941 |         }
1942 | 
1943 | 	/**
1944 | 	 **  FOUND.
1945 | 	 **  free up everything which has been allocated and return on success
1946 | 	 **/
1947 | 	goto success0;
1948 |     }
1949 | 
1950 |     /**
1951 |      **  NOT FOUND. Free up everything which has been alloc'd and return on
1952 |      **  failure
1953 |      **/
1954 | 
1955 | unwind2:
1956 |     if( l_modulefiles)
1957 | 	null_free((void *) &l_modulefiles);
1958 | unwind1:
1959 |     null_free((void *) &l_modules);
1960 | unwind0:
1961 |     return( 0);				/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1962 | 
1963 | success0:
1964 |     if( l_modulefiles)
1965 | 	null_free((void *) &l_modulefiles);
1966 |     null_free((void *) &l_modules);
1967 |     return( 1);				/** -------- EXIT (SUCCESS) -------> **/
1968 | 
1969 | } /** End of '__IsLoaded' **/
1970 | 
1971 | /*++++
1972 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1973 |  ** 									     **
1974 |  **   Function:		chk_marked_entry, set_marked_entry		     **
1975 |  ** 									     **
1976 |  **   Description:	When switching, the variables are marked with a mar- **
1977 |  **			ker that is tested to see if the variable was changed**
1978 |  **			in the second modulefile. If it was not, then the    **
1979 |  **			variable is unset.				     **
1980 |  ** 									     **
1981 |  **   First Edition:	1992/10/25					     **
1982 |  ** 									     **
1983 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_HashTable   *table	Attached hash table	     **
1984 |  **			char            *var	According variable name	     **
1985 |  **			int              val	Value to be set.	     **
1986 |  **									     **
1987 |  **   Result:		int	0	Mark not set (or the value of the    **
1988 |  **					mark was 0 ;-)			     **
1989 |  **				else	Value of the mark that has been set  **
1990 |  **					with set_marked_entry.		     **
1991 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
1992 |  ** 									     **
1993 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1994 |  ++++*/
1995 | 
1996 | intptr_t chk_marked_entry(	Tcl_HashTable	*table,
1997 | 				char		*var)
1998 | {
1999 |     Tcl_HashEntry 	*hentry;
2000 | 
2001 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2002 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_chk_marked_entry, NULL);
2003 | #endif
2004 | 
2005 |     if( (hentry = Tcl_FindHashEntry( table, var)) )
2006 |         return((intptr_t) Tcl_GetHashValue( hentry));
2007 |     else
2008 |         return 0;
2009 | }
2010 | 
2011 | void set_marked_entry(	Tcl_HashTable	*table,
2012 | 			char		*var,
2013 | 			intptr_t 	 val)
2014 | {
2015 |     Tcl_HashEntry	*hentry;
2016 |     int    		 new;
2017 | 
2018 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2019 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_set_marked_entry, NULL);
2020 | #endif
2021 | 
2022 |     if( (hentry = Tcl_CreateHashEntry( table, var, &new)) ) {
2023 |         if( val)
2024 |             Tcl_SetHashValue( hentry, val);
2025 |     }
2026 | 
2027 |     /**  ??? Shouldn't there be an error return in case of hash creation
2028 | 	     failing ??? **/
2029 | }
2030 | 
2031 | /*++++
2032 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2033 |  ** 									     **
2034 |  **   Function:		get_module_basename				     **
2035 |  ** 									     **
2036 |  **   Description:	Get the name of a module without its version.	     **
2037 |  **			This function modifies the string passed in.	     **
2038 |  ** 									     **
2039 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2040 |  ** 									     **
2041 |  **   Parameters:	char	*modulename		Full module name     **
2042 |  ** 									     **
2043 |  **   Result:		char*		Module name without version	     **
2044 |  ** 									     **
2045 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
2046 |  ** 									     **
2047 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2048 |  ++++*/
2049 | 
2050 | static	char	*get_module_basename(	char	*modulename)
2051 | {
2052 |     char *version;			/** Used to locate the version sep.  **/
2053 |     
2054 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2055 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_get_module_basename, NULL);
2056 | #endif
2057 | 
2058 |     /**
2059 |      **  Use strrchr to locate the very last version string on the module
2060 |      **  name.
2061 |      **/
2062 |     if((version = strrchr( modulename, '/'))) {
2063 | 	*version = '\0';
2064 |     } else {
2065 | 	modulename = NULL;
2066 |     }
2067 |  
2068 |     /**
2069 |      **  Return the *COPIED* string
2070 |      **/
2071 |     return( modulename);
2072 | 
2073 | } /** End of 'get_module_basename' **/
2074 | 
2075 | /*++++
2076 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2077 |  ** 									     **
2078 |  **   Function:		Update_LoadedList				     **
2079 |  ** 									     **
2080 |  **   Description:	Add or remove the passed modulename and filename to/ **
2081 |  **			from LOADEDMODULES and _LMFILES_		     **
2082 |  ** 									     **
2083 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2084 |  ** 									     **
2085 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp      *interp		Attached Tcl Interp. **
2086 |  **			char            *modulename	Name of the module   **
2087 |  **			char            *filename	Full path name of the**
2088 |  **							related modulefile   **
2089 |  **									     **
2090 |  **   Result:		int	1	Successful operation		     **
2091 |  **									     **
2092 |  **   Attached Globals:	g_flags		Controls whether the modulename      **
2093 |  **					should be added (M_XXXX) or removed  **
2094 |  **					(M_REMOVE) from the list of loaded   **
2095 |  **					modules				     **
2096 |  ** 									     **
2097 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2098 |  ++++*/
2099 | 
2100 | int Update_LoadedList(	Tcl_Interp	*interp,
2101 | 			char		*modulename,
2102 | 			char		*filename)
2103 | {
2104 |     char 	*argv[4];
2105 |     char	*basename;
2106 |     char	*module;
2107 |  
2108 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2109 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Update_LoadedList, NULL);
2110 | #endif
2111 | 
2112 |     /**
2113 |      **  Apply changes to LOADEDMODULES first
2114 |      **/
2115 |     argv[1] = "LOADEDMODULES";
2116 |     argv[2] = modulename;
2117 |     argv[3] = NULL;
2118 |     
2119 |     if(g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
2120 | 	argv[0] = "remove-path";
2121 | 	cmdRemovePath( 0, interp, 3, (CONST84 char **) argv);
2122 |     } else {
2123 | 	argv[0] = "append-path";
2124 | 	cmdSetPath( 0, interp, 3, (CONST84 char **) argv);
2125 |     }
2126 |  
2127 |     /**
2128 |      **  Apply changes to _LMFILES_ now
2129 |      **/
2130 |     argv[1] = "_LMFILES_";
2131 |     argv[2] = filename;
2132 |     argv[3] = NULL;
2133 | 
2134 |     if(g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
2135 | 	argv[0] = "remove-path";
2136 | 	cmdRemovePath( 0, interp, 3, (CONST84 char **) argv);
2137 |     } else {
2138 | 	argv[0] = "append-path";
2139 | 	cmdSetPath( 0, interp, 3, (CONST84 char **) argv);
2140 |     }
2141 | 
2142 |     /**
2143 |      **  A module with just the basename might have been added and now we're
2144 |      **  removing one of its versions. We'll want to look for the basename in
2145 |      **  the path too.
2146 |      **/
2147 |     if( g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
2148 | 	module = stringer(NULL,0, modulename, NULL);
2149 | 	basename = module;
2150 | 	if( (basename = get_module_basename( basename)) ) {
2151 | 	argv[2] = basename;
2152 | 	argv[0] = "remove-path";
2153 | 	cmdRemovePath( 0, interp, 3, (CONST84 char **) argv);
2154 | 	}
2155 | 	null_free((void *) &module);
2156 |     }
2157 | 
2158 |     /**
2159 |      **  Return on success
2160 |      **/
2161 |     return( 1);
2162 | 
2163 | } /** End of 'Update_LoadedList' **/
2164 | 
2165 | /*++++
2166 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2167 |  ** 									     **
2168 |  **   Function:		check_magic					     **
2169 |  ** 									     **
2170 |  **   Description:	Check the magic cookie of the file passed as para-   **
2171 |  **			meter if it is a valid module file		     **
2172 |  **			Based on check_magic in Richard Elling's	     **
2173 |  **			find_by_magic <Richard.Elling"@eng.auburn.edu>	     **
2174 |  ** 									     **
2175 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2176 |  ** 									     **
2177 |  **   Parameters:	char   *filename	Name of the file to check    **
2178 |  **			char   *magic_name	Magic cookie		     **
2179 |  **			int     magic_len	Length of the magic cookie   **
2180 |  ** 									     **
2181 |  **   Result:		int	0	Magic cookie doesn't match or any    **
2182 |  **					I/O error			     **
2183 |  **				1	Success - Magic cookie has matched   **
2184 |  ** 									     **
2185 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
2186 |  ** 									     **
2187 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2188 |  ++++*/
2189 | 
2190 | int check_magic( char	*filename,
2191 | 		 char	*magic_name,
2192 | 		 int	 magic_len)
2193 | {
2194 |     int  fd;				/** File descriptor for reading in   **/
2195 |     int  read_len;			/** Number of bytes read	     **/
2196 |     char buf[BUFSIZ];			/** Read buffer			     **/
2197 | 
2198 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2199 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_check_magic, NULL);
2200 | #endif
2201 | 
2202 |     /**
2203 |      **  Parameter check. The length of the magic cookie shouldn't exceed the
2204 |      **  length of out read buffer
2205 |      **/
2206 |     if( magic_len > BUFSIZ)
2207 | 	return 0;
2208 | 
2209 |     /**
2210 |      **  Open the file and read in as many bytes as required for checking the
2211 |      **  magic cookie. If there's an I/O error (Unable to open the file or
2212 |      **  less than magic_len have been read) return on failure.
2213 |      **/
2214 |     if( 0 > (fd = open( filename, O_RDONLY)))
2215 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_OPEN, LOC, filename, _(em_reading), NULL))
2216 | 	    return( 0);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
2217 | 
2218 |     read_len = read( fd, buf, magic_len);
2219 |     
2220 |     if( 0 > close(fd))
2221 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, filename, NULL))
2222 | 	    return( 0);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
2223 | 
2224 |     if( read_len < magic_len)
2225 | 	return( 0);
2226 | 
2227 |     /**
2228 |      **  Check the magic cookie now
2229 |      **/
2230 |     return( !strncmp( buf, magic_name, magic_len));
2231 | 
2232 | } /** end of 'check_magic' **/
2233 | 
2234 | /*++++
2235 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2236 |  ** 									     **
2237 |  **   Function:		cleanse_path					     **
2238 |  ** 									     **
2239 |  **   Description:	Copy the passed path into the new path buffer and    **
2240 |  **			devalue '.' and '+'				     **
2241 |  ** 									     **
2242 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2243 |  ** 									     **
2244 |  **   Parameters:	const char   *path	Original path		     **
2245 |  **			      char   *newpath	Buffer for to copy the new   **
2246 |  **						path in			     **
2247 |  **			      int     len	Max length of the new path   **
2248 |  **									     **
2249 |  **   Result:		newpath		will be filled up with the new, de-  **
2250 |  **					valuated path			     **
2251 |  **									     **
2252 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
2253 |  ** 									     **
2254 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2255 |  ++++*/
2256 | 
2257 | void cleanse_path( const char	*path,
2258 | 		         char	*newpath,
2259 | 			 int	 len)
2260 | {
2261 |     unsigned int path_len = strlen( path);	/** Length of the orig. path **/
2262 |     int 	 i,				/** Read index		     **/
2263 |     		 j;				/** Write index		     **/
2264 | 
2265 | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
2266 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_cleanse_path, NULL);
2267 | #endif
2268 | 
2269 |     /**
2270 |      **  Stopping at (len - 1) ensures that the newpath string can be
2271 |      **  null-terminated below.
2272 |      **/
2273 |     for( i=0, j=0; i<path_len && j<(len - 1); i++, j++) {
2274 | 
2275 |         switch(*path) {
2276 |             case '.':
2277 |             case '+':
2278 |             case '$':
2279 | 		*newpath++ = '\\';		/** devalue '.' and '+'	    **/
2280 | 		j++;
2281 | 		break;
2282 |         }
2283 | 
2284 | 	/**
2285 | 	 **  Flush the current character into the newpath buffer
2286 | 	 **/
2287 |         *newpath++ = *path++;
2288 | 
2289 |     } /** for **/
2290 | 
2291 |     /**
2292 |      **  Put a string terminator at the newpaths end
2293 |      **/
2294 |     *newpath = '\0';
2295 | 
2296 | } /** End of 'cleanse_path' **/
2297 | 
2298 | /*++++
2299 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2300 |  ** 									     **
2301 |  **   Function:		chop						     **
2302 |  ** 									     **
2303 |  **   Description:	Remove '\n' characters from the passed string	     **
2304 |  ** 									     **
2305 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2306 |  ** 									     **
2307 |  **   Parameters:	char   *string	String to be chopped		     **
2308 |  **									     **
